content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Look up the use of modal verbs in grammar section for expressing possibility (e.g., 'might', 'could', 'may') and find examples of their usage in sentences on the Cambridge Dictionary.  Please interact with https://dictionary.cambridge.org/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The task is to find information in the grammar section about modal verbs used for expressing possibility and to look for example sentences. The "Grammar" section should have this information. 
Action: Click [3]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "Explore the English Grammar" page is loaded, but a pop-up is covering part of the screen, potentially interfering with navigation or content visibility. Closing the pop-up would provide a clearer view and easier access to the grammar resources.
Action: Click [26]
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.3
The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.

Thought: The pop-up is partially blocking the content. The most likely option to close this pop-up and continue accessing the grammar section is to click the "Accept All Cookies" button, which is common for such pop-ups. This should make the page fully accessible for further navigation.
Action: Click [25]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The pop-up is gone and the "Explore the English Grammar" section is visible. The page likely contains links or headings related to grammar topics, including modal verbs. I need to scroll down to find content about modal verbs, especially their use for expressing possibility.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.35
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Since the task is about modal verbs like "might," "could," and "may" used for expressing possibility, the most relevant section to look for this information is under "Verbs."
Action: Click [19]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.5
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I am in the "Verbs" section, and modal verbs are typically discussed as part of verb forms or patterns. I should look for modals under "Verb forms," which likely contains information about modal verbs.
Action: Click [27]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.6
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "Verb forms" section discusses main verbs and their forms but does not mention modal verbs yet. Modal verbs are sometimes listed as a separate subcategory or included in related patterns. I should check the "Contents" link to navigate to the relevant modal verbs or possibility section within verbs.
Action: Click [31]
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.65
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The contents sidebar is visible. To find information on modal verbs for expressing possibility, the most logical choice is to expand "Verbs" since modal verbs are part of this category.
Action: Click [12]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.7
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The contents section now shows a "Modal verbs and modality" link, which is directly related to the task about expressing possibility with modal verbs. Clicking this section should lead to explanations and examples of modal verbs like 'might', 'could', and 'may'.
Action: Click [23]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.8

content:
Thought: The explanation for using "could," "may," and "might" to express degrees of possibility is visible: "We use could, may and might to express degrees of possibility." There is also an example sentence: "The restaurant may close."
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.95

content.text:
Observation: please analyze the attached screenshot and give the Thought and Action. I've provided the tag name of each element and the text it contains (if text exists). Note that <textarea> or <input> may be textbox, but not exactly. Please focus more on the screenshot and then refer to the textual information.
[1]: "Dictionary";	[2]: "Translate";	[3]: "Grammar";	[4]: "Thesaurus";	[5]: "+Plus Cambridge Dictionary +Plus";	[10]: "Log in";	[11]: "Sign up";	[13]: "English (UK)";	[15]: "The restaurant could close.";	[16]: "It is less likely that the restaurant will close.";	[17]: "The restaurant might close.";	[18]: "There is only a possibility that the restaurant will close but no one is very sure.";	[23]: "fault";	[24]: "To top";	[27]: "Contents";

content:
Thought: More examples of modal verbs for expressing possibility are visible: "The restaurant could close." and "The restaurant might close." Each is accompanied by an explanation of the degree of possibility. This fulfills the task requirements for usage and examples.
Action: ANSWER; The Cambridge Dictionary explains that "could," "may," and "might" are used to express degrees of possibility. Examples from the grammar section:
- "The restaurant may close." (It is likely that the restaurant will close.)
- "The restaurant could close." (It is less likely that the restaurant will close.)
- "The restaurant might close." (There is only a possibility that the restaurant will close but no one is very sure.)
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 1.0
token:
: ANSWER; The Cambridge Dictionary explains that "could," "may," and "might" are used to express degrees of possibility. Examples from the grammar section:
- "The restaurant may close." (It is likely that the restaurant will close.)
- "The restaurant could close." (It is less likely that the restaurant will close.)
- "The restaurant might close." (There is only a possibility that the restaurant will close but no one is very sure.)
